file_content.text: Your CO sent orders to do whatever is necessary to support your mission. Of course, she didn't see fit to tell me what that mission is--care to enlighten me?
I'm afraid I can't, Colonel.
Typical. Forget the reconstruction of Taris--I've got to shift everything around and help with some "top secret mission" nonsense!
A group of SpecForce soldiers have defected. I'm here to find them.
I'm hunting down traitors.
Huh. No wonder Garza's in such a frenzy.
Well, you won't find any traitors hiding on Taris, Lieutenant. We haven't seen any unusual activity since I took command.
What mission? I'm here on vacation.
I don't know what you mean.
Very funny, Lieutenant. But I don't appreciate having my time wasted.
Whatever Garza has you looking for, you won't find it on Taris. Nothing unusual has happened since I took command.
Patrol teams three, five and eight. All lost, all without explanation.
Sergeant Dorne, I don't recall giving you permission to speak.
I wasn't speaking to you--I was speaking to the lieutenant, per General Garza's instructions. Are you ordering me to violate Code 73-B and ignore the general's directive, Colonel?
Always got a regulation to quote, don't you, Sergeant Dorne?
If the sergeant has information, I'll take it.
Let's hear her out.
The matter was settled days ago.
I came here for intel, not arguments, people.
Cram the bickering.
I already told you, Lieutenant, there's nothing to find here.
I don't like it when people hide things from me.
Start talking, Gaff.
Who do you think you are, Lieutenant? That Havoc badge does not mean you can just ignore the chain of command!
Taris is dangerous--casualties are common on patrol teams. It's unfortunate, but not unusual, no matter what Sergeant Dorne says.
Now, if you'll excuse me, I've got a planet to run. Carry on with your "secret mission"--just don't muck up anything important.
Apologies for the colonel, Lieutenant. Not all men are meant to lead.
Colonel Gaff is disobeying a direct order.
You can say that again.
I can assure you, it's not the first time he's done so.
The colonel has his rank for a reason. We shouldn't question him.
It's not our place to judge.
Regulation 5.3 compels us to report all officer misconduct. The command structure must be effective.
If you have information that could help me, I'd like to hear it.
Do you have intel for me?
Very well, Lieutenant.
I'm Elara Dorne, sir. Sergeant, first class, commander of Search and Rescue Squad 204.
We have three full squads, all MIA on patrols. The situation is critical.
Do you have any idea what happened to these men?
What do we know?
I'm afraid not, Lieutenant.
Why is this so critical?
Eighteen unexplained casualties over two weeks. Regulations call for a battalion-level investigation, but nothing has been done.
I'm not here to find missing patrols, Dorne.
Search-and-rescue is your job.
Understood, Lieutenant. But the threat behind these MIAs could be tied to your mission.
Casualties are common on swamp patrols. Rakghoul attacks account for the majority--approximately eighty-seven percent.
However, SAR sweeps discovered no evidence of rakghoul activity in these instances--someone else attacked those teams. If you're looking for unusual activity, then this is it, sir.
I appreciate your help, Sergeant.
Thank you.
What exactly is a "rakghoul," anyway?
Tell me about the rakghouls.
Rakghouls are disease-carrying mutants. Rakghoul bites and scratches are infectious. Those infected become rakghouls themselves in six to forty-eight hours.
I'll decide for myself what's important, Dorne.
This isn't your call to make.
Understood, Lieutenant. General Garza's orders were to apprise you of all pertinent intelligence.
I included the last known coordinates for the MIA patrols in my official incident report, Lieutenant. I'll load it onto your datapad for your review.
Taris falls under unexplored/unsecured territory protocols--all armor-cams transmit to SAR Command. I'll contact you with developments.
Sounds like a plan, Sergeant.
Very well.
You aren't authorized to observe my mission, Sergeant.
I don't think so.
Security Code MR-7-C grants temporary authorization in this situation.
You'd better not be wasting my time, Dorne.
This better be worth it.
I don't waste time.
Good luck, Lieutenant.
That was... interesting. I've had drill instructors more relaxed than that woman. Not to mention that accent.
The locals can run things however they want. We've got our own mission to worry about.
Let's just stick to the job.
What do you mean? What's unusual about her accent?
Accent?
The only people I've heard talk like that were Imperials. The Republic must have freed her homeworld in the war--growing up Imp would explain a lot about her personality.
I'd say the Republic could use more officers like Dorne.
Nothing wrong with discipline.
And I'd say there's better uses for a soldier's time than memorizing every single regulation in the books.
"Uptight" doesn't even begin to describe that woman.
No kidding.
Let's just get on with the mission, Jorgan.
Not our concern.
You're the boss. Lead the way, Lieutenant.
Who cares if the woman is uptight? She's gorgeous!
I only noticed her looks.
You want to take a shot at her, you go right ahead. I'm sure it'll work out really well.
Has little Jorgan finally met his dream girl?
Why so interested?
Don't be ridiculous. Uh, Lieutenant. I'm sorry I said anything.
Guess it's off to work, then. I'll watch our backs.
I'll be in the SAR office if you require further support, Lieutenant. Farewell.
Well, well. General Garza graces us with her finest. At ease--I'm Colonel Gaff, and these are my senior officers.
Intriguing. A fine example of the Republic's officer training, coupled with the accent of our tyrannous Imperial enemies. Very strange.
Sergeant Dorne isn't our concern. We've got a mission to worry about.
Let's just stick to the job.
What are you talking about, Forex? What's wrong with her accent?
Tyrannous accent?
All other subjects I've observed with similar affects were Imperial officers. It seems to be a common speech variation on Imperial-controlled worlds.
Since the sergeant is clearly an exemplary servant of our glorious Republic, one can only assume she was raised on an Imperial world that was liberated by our noble forces.
We'll just have to ask Sergeant Dorne about it sometime.
You're probably right.
We'd better keep our eyes open on this one, Forex.
It's still suspicious.
I will remain vigilant as ever.
Let's get on with our mission, Forex.
Not our concern.
As you say, Lieutenant! Lead the way!
All I care about are the sergeant's physical attributes, Forex.
I only noticed her looks.
Yes, the truest measure of soldiers' worth is in their physical capabilities--strength, speed, and endurance. Your discerning eye marks you as an experienced officer.
You're really odd, Forex, do you know that?
I am as the Republic made me. If I am odd, then I am sure it serves the greater purposes of freedom and democracy.
Let us proceed with our mission. I will follow your lead, Lieutenant.
